sn11.3:1.1.comm: This discourse invokes several major Vedic deities invoked as martial deities, gods of war. Compare their mention at DN 13:25.2, where these deities, though aristocrat warriors, are invoked by brahmins. In Theravada it is a popular protection chant (paritta) included in the Maha Pirit Potha.

sn11.3:1.2.eng: There the Buddha addressed the mendicants,

sn11.3:2.1.eng: “Once upon a time, mendicants, a battle was fought between the gods and the titans.

sn11.3:2.2.pli: Atha kho, bhikkhave, sakko devānamindo deve tāvatiṃse āmantesi:
sn11.3:2.2.eng: Then Sakka, lord of gods, addressed the gods of the thirty-three:

sn11.3:3.1.pli: ‘Sace, mārisā, devānaṃ saṅgāmagatānaṃ uppajjeyya bhayaṃ vā chambhitattaṃ vā lomahaṃso vā, mameva tasmiṃ samaye dhajaggaṃ ullokeyyātha.
sn11.3:3.1.eng: ‘Good fellows, when the gods are fighting, if you get scared or terrified, just look up at my banner’s crest.
sn11.3:3.1.comm: Compare the martial exhortation at Rig Veda 10.103.11: “Ours is Indra when the banners clash.” Varāhamihira tells the full story of Indra’s banner at Bṛhatsaṁhitā 42.

sn11.3:3.2.pli: Mamañhi vo dhajaggaṃ ullokayataṃ yaṃ bhavissati bhayaṃ vā chambhitattaṃ vā lomahaṃso vā, so pahīyissati.
sn11.3:3.2.eng: Then your fear and terror will go away.

sn11.3:4.1.pli: No ce me dhajaggaṃ ullokeyyātha, atha pajāpatissa devarājassa dhajaggaṃ ullokeyyātha.
sn11.3:4.1.eng: If you can’t see my banner’s crest, then look up at the banner’s crest of the Progenitor, king of gods.
sn11.3:4.1.comm: Pajāpati (“progenitor”) was the lonely and “undefined” (anirukta) god of creation (“Let Prajāpati generate progeny for us”, Rig Veda 10.85.3). The heat of his fervent exertions (tapas) created the world and all things in it (Śatapatha Brāhmaṇa 6).

sn11.3:4.2.pli: Pajāpatissa hi vo devarājassa dhajaggaṃ ullokayataṃ yaṃ bhavissati bhayaṃ vā chambhitattaṃ vā lomahaṃso vā, so pahīyissati.
sn11.3:4.2.eng: Then your fear and terror will go away.

sn11.3:5.1.pli: No ce pajāpatissa devarājassa dhajaggaṃ ullokeyyātha, atha varuṇassa devarājassa dhajaggaṃ ullokeyyātha.
sn11.3:5.1.eng: If you can’t see his banner’s crest, then look up at the banner’s crest of Varuṇa, king of gods.
sn11.3:5.1.comm: Varuṇa is invoked frequently in the Vedas, and in the suttas he is associated with other leading deities such as Indra and Soma (DN 13:25.2, DN 20:13.3,DN 32:10.2). As one of the twelve children of Aditi he stood for a calendar month, and grew a wide and sometimes baffling array of associations—the oceans, water, the sky (at night), and justice. Vedic Varuṇa was the god of command, the king of tough rule. He was identified with the aristocrats, his partner Mitra with the brahmins (Śatapatha Brāhmaṇa 4.1.4).

sn11.3:5.2.pli: Varuṇassa hi vo devarājassa dhajaggaṃ ullokayataṃ yaṃ bhavissati bhayaṃ vā chambhitattaṃ vā lomahaṃso vā, so pahīyissati.
sn11.3:5.2.eng: Then your fear and terror will go away.

sn11.3:6.1.pli: No ce varuṇassa devarājassa dhajaggaṃ ullokeyyātha, atha īsānassa devarājassa dhajaggaṃ ullokeyyātha.
sn11.3:6.1.eng: If you can’t see his banner’s crest, then look up at the banner’s crest of Īsāna, king of gods.
sn11.3:6.1.comm: Īsāna (Sanskrit Īśāna) was created by Pajāpati as “president”, said to be the sun (Śatapatha Brāhmaṇa 6.1.3). He was also identified with Rudra and Śiva.

sn11.3:6.2.pli: Īsānassa hi vo devarājassa dhajaggaṃ ullokayataṃ yaṃ bhavissati bhayaṃ vā chambhitattaṃ vā lomahaṃso vā, so pahīyissatī’ti.
sn11.3:6.2.eng: Then your fear and terror will go away.’

sn11.3:7.1.pli: Taṃ kho pana, bhikkhave, sakkassa vā devānamindassa dhajaggaṃ ullokayataṃ, pajāpatissa vā devarājassa dhajaggaṃ ullokayataṃ, varuṇassa vā devarājassa dhajaggaṃ ullokayataṃ, īsānassa vā devarājassa dhajaggaṃ ullokayataṃ yaṃ bhavissati bhayaṃ vā chambhitattaṃ vā lomahaṃso vā, so pahīyethāpi nopi pahīyetha.
sn11.3:7.1.eng: However, when they look up at those banner’s crests their fear and terror might go away or it might not.

sn11.3:8.2.pli: Sakko hi, bhikkhave, devānamindo avītarāgo avītadoso avītamoho bhīru chambhī utrāsī palāyīti.
sn11.3:8.2.eng: Because Sakka is not free of greed, hate, and delusion. He is fearful, scared, nervous, quick to flee.

sn11.3:9.2.pli: ‘sace tumhākaṃ, bhikkhave, araññagatānaṃ vā rukkhamūlagatānaṃ vā suññāgāragatānaṃ vā uppajjeyya bhayaṃ vā chambhitattaṃ vā lomahaṃso vā, mameva tasmiṃ samaye anussareyyātha:
sn11.3:9.2.eng: If you’ve gone to a wilderness, or to the root of a tree, or to an empty hut and you get scared or terrified, just recollect me:

sn11.3:9.3.pli: “itipi so bhagavā arahaṃ sammāsambuddho vijjācaraṇasampanno sugato lokavidū anuttaro purisadammasārathi satthā devamanussānaṃ buddho bhagavā”ti.
sn11.3:9.3.eng: ‘That Blessed One is perfected, a fully awakened Buddha, accomplished in knowledge and conduct, holy, knower of the world, supreme guide for those fit for training, teacher of gods and humans, awakened, blessed.’

sn11.3:9.4.pli: Mamañhi vo, bhikkhave, anussarataṃ yaṃ bhavissati bhayaṃ vā chambhitattaṃ vā lomahaṃso vā, so pahīyissati.
sn11.3:9.4.eng: Then your fear and terror will go away.

sn11.3:10.1.pli: No ce maṃ anussareyyātha, atha dhammaṃ anussareyyātha:
sn11.3:10.1.eng: If you can’t recollect me, then recollect the teaching:

sn11.3:10.2.pli: “svākkhāto bhagavatā dhammo sandiṭṭhiko akāliko ehipassiko opaneyyiko paccattaṃ veditabbo viññūhī”ti.
sn11.3:10.2.eng: ‘The teaching is well explained by the Buddha—apparent in the present life, immediately effective, inviting inspection, relevant, so that sensible people can know it for themselves.’

sn11.3:10.3.pli: Dhammañhi vo, bhikkhave, anussarataṃ yaṃ bhavissati bhayaṃ vā chambhitattaṃ vā lomahaṃso vā, so pahīyissati.
sn11.3:10.3.eng: Then your fear and terror will go away.

sn11.3:11.1.pli: No ce dhammaṃ anussareyyātha, atha saṅghaṃ anussareyyātha:
sn11.3:11.1.eng: If you can’t recollect the teaching, then recollect the Saṅgha:

sn11.3:11.2.pli: “suppaṭipanno bhagavato sāvakasaṅgho ujuppaṭipanno bhagavato sāvakasaṅgho ñāyappaṭipanno bhagavato sāvakasaṅgho sāmīcippaṭipanno bhagavato sāvakasaṅgho, yadidaṃ cattāri purisayugāni aṭṭha purisapuggalā esa bhagavato sāvakasaṅgho, āhuneyyo pāhuneyyo dakkhiṇeyyo añjalikaraṇīyo anuttaraṃ puññakkhettaṃ lokassā”ti.
sn11.3:11.2.eng: ‘The Saṅgha of the Buddha’s disciples is practicing the way that’s good, direct, systematic, and proper. It consists of the four pairs, the eight individual persons. This is the Saṅgha of the Buddha’s disciples that is worthy of offerings dedicated to the gods, worthy of hospitality, worthy of a religious donation, worthy of greeting with joined palms, and is the supreme field of merit for the world.’

sn11.3:11.3.pli: Saṅghañhi vo, bhikkhave, anussarataṃ yaṃ bhavissati bhayaṃ vā chambhitattaṃ vā lomahaṃso vā, so pahīyissati.
sn11.3:11.3.eng: Then your fear and terror will go away.

sn11.3:12.2.pli: Tathāgato hi, bhikkhave, arahaṃ sammāsambuddho vītarāgo vītadoso vītamoho abhīru acchambhī anutrāsī apalāyī’”ti.
sn11.3:12.2.eng: Because the Realized One is free of greed, hate, and delusion. He is fearless, brave, bold, and stands his ground.”

sn11.3:12.3.eng: That is what the Buddha said.

sn11.3:12.4.pli: Idaṃ vatvāna sugato athāparaṃ etadavoca satthā:
sn11.3:12.4.eng: Then the Holy One, the Teacher, went on to say:

sn11.3:13.1.eng: “In the wilderness, at a tree’s root,

sn11.3:13.2.eng: or an empty hut, O mendicants,

sn11.3:13.4.eng: and no fear will come to you.

sn11.3:14.1.eng: If you can’t recollect the Buddha—

sn11.3:14.2.eng: the eldest in the world, the captain of men—
sn11.3:14.2.comm: Narāsabha is literally “a bull of a man”, but the predominant sense is “chief, lord, captain” rather than “bull”. Vṛṣabha was widely used in this sense as far back as the Rig Veda. The same is true of its synonyms janavasabha and purisanisabha, but not purisūsabha at Bu Pj 1:10.21.4.

sn11.3:15.1.eng: If you can’t recollect the teaching—

sn11.3:16.2.eng: the teaching, and the Saṅgha, mendicants,

sn11.3:16.4.eng: and goosebumps will be no more.”

sn11.4:1.2.eng: “Once upon a time, mendicants, a battle was fought between the gods and the titans.

sn11.4:1.3.pli: Atha kho, bhikkhave, vepacitti asurindo asure āmantesi:
sn11.4:1.3.eng: Then Vepacitti, lord of titans, addressed the titans,
sn11.4:1.3.comm: Vepacitti (“wise thinker”) was the lord of the asuras and Sakka’s counterpart; their relationship status is complicated. The Sanskrit form is vipracitti, but in Buddhist texts it is incorrectly Sanskritized to vemacitra. He seems not to appear in early Sanskrit texts, but the Mahābhārata and Purāṇas regard him as the eldest son of Danū and hence chief of the Dānavas.

sn11.4:1.4.pli: ‘sace, mārisā, devānaṃ asurasaṅgāme samupabyūḷhe asurā jineyyuṃ devā parājineyyuṃ, yena naṃ sakkaṃ devānamindaṃ kaṇṭhapañcamehi bandhanehi bandhitvā mama santike āneyyātha asurapuran’ti.
sn11.4:1.4.eng: ‘My good fellows, if the titans defeat the gods in this battle, bind Sakka, the lord of gods, by his limbs and neck and bring him to my presence in the citadel of the titans.’

sn11.4:1.5.pli: Sakkopi kho, bhikkhave, devānamindo deve tāvatiṃse āmantesi:
sn11.4:1.5.eng: Meanwhile, Sakka, lord of gods, addressed the gods of the thirty-three,

sn11.4:1.6.pli: ‘sace, mārisā, devānaṃ asurasaṅgāme samupabyūḷhe devā jineyyuṃ asurā parājineyyuṃ, yena naṃ vepacittiṃ asurindaṃ kaṇṭhapañcamehi bandhanehi bandhitvā mama santike āneyyātha sudhammasabhan’ti.
sn11.4:1.6.eng: ‘My good fellows, if the gods defeat the titans in this battle, bind Vepacitti by his limbs and neck and bring him to my presence in the Hall of Clear Right of the gods.’

sn11.4:1.7.pli: Tasmiṃ kho pana, bhikkhave, saṅgāme devā jiniṃsu, asurā parājiniṃsu.
sn11.4:1.7.eng: In that battle the gods won and the titans lost.

sn11.4:1.8.pli: Atha kho, bhikkhave, devā tāvatiṃsā vepacittiṃ asurindaṃ kaṇṭhapañcamehi bandhanehi bandhitvā sakkassa devānamindassa santike ānesuṃ sudhammasabhaṃ.
sn11.4:1.8.eng: So the gods of the thirty-three bound Vepacitti by his limbs and neck and brought him to Sakka’s presence in the Hall of Clear Right of the gods.

sn11.4:1.9.pli: Tatra sudaṃ, bhikkhave, vepacitti asurindo kaṇṭhapañcamehi bandhanehi baddho sakkaṃ devānamindaṃ sudhammasabhaṃ pavisantañca nikkhamantañca asabbhāhi pharusāhi vācāhi akkosati paribhāsati.
sn11.4:1.9.eng: And as Sakka was entering and leaving the hall, Vepacitti abused and insulted him with rude, harsh words.
sn11.4:1.9.comm: It seems they had strong feelings for each other.

sn11.4:1.10.pli: Atha kho, bhikkhave, mātali saṅgāhako sakkaṃ devānamindaṃ gāthāhi ajjhabhāsi:
sn11.4:1.10.eng: So Mātali the chariot handler addressed Sakka in verse,
sn11.4:1.10.comm: Mātali is the charioteer of Sakka. He appears at DN 20:10.8 as one of the centaur lords, and is father to the centaur Sikhaṇḍī, Pañcasikha’s rival in love (DN 21:1.6.8). In Pali, he is never addressed with the usual word for charioteer (sārathi), but by the epithet saṅgāhaka, literally “gatherer” in the sense “one who holds the reins”, here “chariot handler”, recalling the centaur who took the reins from Indra (Rig Veda 1.163.2). Later Brahmanical literature also knows him as Indra’s charioteer, but pre-Buddhist references are few and obscure. He flourishes in the land of Yama along with the poets (Rig Veda 10.14.3 = Atharva Veda 18.1.47); he is made of magic (Atharva Veda 8.9.5); he knows the immortal balm bought by a chariot’s price that is infused by Indra in the waters (Atharva Veda 11.6.23).

sn11.4:2.1.comm: For Sakka’s epithets, see SN 11.12 and notes there.

sn11.4:2.2.eng: is it from fear or from weakness

sn11.4:2.3.eng: that you withstand such harsh words

sn11.4:3.1.eng: ‘It’s not out of fear or weakness

sn11.4:3.3.eng: For how can a sensible person like me

sn11.4:3.4.eng: get in a fight with a fool?’

sn11.4:4.2.eng: if there’s no-one to put a stop to them.

sn11.4:4.3.eng: So a wise one should stop

sn11.4:4.4.comm: Throughout this chapter, Mātali displays more of the old martial character, and Sakka leads him to growth, as he does for the titans.

sn11.4:5.1.eng: ‘I think that this is the only way

sn11.4:5.2.eng: to put a stop to a fool,

sn11.4:5.3.eng: when you know that the other is upset,

sn11.4:6.5.eng: the simpleton will go after you even harder,

sn11.4:6.6.eng: like a cow chasing someone who runs away.’

sn11.4:7.1.eng: ‘Let him think this if he wishes, or not—

sn11.4:7.3.eng: For the highest goal, one’s own,
sn11.4:7.3.comm: I take sadatthaparamā atthā as truncated dative of purpose; see discussion at SN 11.8:2.2.

sn11.4:7.4.eng: naught better than patience is found.

sn11.4:8.3.eng: they call that the ultimate patience,

sn11.4:8.4.eng: for a weakling must always be patient.

sn11.4:9.2.eng: is really just weakness, they say.

sn11.4:9.3.eng: But no-one can challenge a person

sn11.4:9.4.eng: who’s strong, guarded by the teaching.

sn11.4:10.1.eng: When you get angry at an angry person

sn11.4:10.2.eng: you just make things worse for yourself.

sn11.4:10.3.eng: When you don’t get angry at an angry person

sn11.4:10.4.eng: you win a battle hard to win.

sn11.4:11.1.eng: When you know that the other is angry,

sn11.4:11.2.eng: you act for the good of both

sn11.4:11.4.eng: if you’re mindful and stay calm.

sn11.4:13.1.pli: So hi nāma, bhikkhave, sakko devānamindo sakaṃ puññaphalaṃ upajīvamāno devānaṃ tāvatiṃsānaṃ issariyādhipaccaṃ rajjaṃ kārento khantisoraccassa vaṇṇavādī bhavissati.
sn11.4:13.1.eng: Since, mendicants, even that Sakka, lord of gods—while living off of the fruit of his good deeds, and ruling as sovereign lord over these gods of the thirty-three—will speak in praise of patience and gentleness,

sn11.4:13.2.pli: Idha kho taṃ, bhikkhave, sobhetha yaṃ tumhe evaṃ svākkhāte dhammavinaye pabbajitā samānā khamā ca bhaveyyātha soratā cā”ti.
sn11.4:13.2.eng: you can excel at this, for you who have gone forth in such a well explained teaching and training can develop patience and gentleness.”

sn11.5:1.2.eng: “Once upon a time, mendicants, a battle was fought between the gods and the titans.

sn11.5:1.3.pli: Atha kho, bhikkhave, vepacitti asurindo sakkaṃ devānamindaṃ etadavoca:
sn11.5:1.3.eng: Then Vepacitti, lord of titans, said to Sakka, lord of gods,

sn11.5:1.4.eng: ‘Lord of gods, let there be victory by fine words!’

sn11.5:1.5.eng: ‘Vepacitti, let there be victory by fine words!’

sn11.5:1.6.pli: Atha kho, bhikkhave, devā ca asurā ca pārisajje ṭhapesuṃ:
sn11.5:1.6.eng: Then the gods and the titans appointed a panel of judges, saying,

sn11.5:1.7.eng: ‘These will understand our good and bad statements.’

sn11.5:1.8.pli: Atha kho, bhikkhave, vepacitti asurindo sakkaṃ devānamindaṃ etadavoca:
sn11.5:1.8.eng: Then Vepacitti, lord of titans, said to Sakka, lord of gods,

sn11.5:1.10.pli: Evaṃ vutte, bhikkhave, sakko devānamindo vepacittiṃ asurindaṃ etadavoca:
sn11.5:1.10.eng: When he said this, Sakka said to him,

sn11.5:1.11.eng: ‘Vepacitti, you are the elder gods here.
sn11.5:1.11.comm: “Elder god” (pubbadeva) because originally the earth belonged to the titans and was tricked from them by employing the verses of the rites (Taittirīya Brāhmaṇa 3.2.9e, cf. Śatapatha Brāhmaṇa 1.2.5.1). This battle by debate recalls Bṛhadāraṇyaka Upaniṣad 1.3.1, which explains that the titans are the elder children of Pajāpati. The younger children, the gods, sought to overcome them by means of reciting the sacred word (udgītha), but the titans pierced it with the evil that is bad speech.

sn11.5:1.13.pli: Evaṃ vutte, bhikkhave, vepacitti asurindo imaṃ gāthaṃ abhāsi:
sn11.5:1.13.comm: Vepacitti adopts the same position as Mātali in the previous discourse.

sn11.5:2.2.eng: if there’s no-one to put a stop to them.

sn11.5:2.3.eng: So an intelligent person should stop

sn11.5:3.1.pli: Bhāsitāya kho pana, bhikkhave, vepacittinā asurindena gāthāya asurā anumodiṃsu, devā tuṇhī ahesuṃ.
sn11.5:3.1.eng: The titans applauded Vepacitti’s verse, while the gods kept silent.

sn11.5:3.2.pli: Atha kho, bhikkhave, vepacitti asurindo sakkaṃ devānamindaṃ etadavoca:

sn11.5:3.4.pli: Evaṃ vutte, bhikkhave, sakko devānamindo imaṃ gāthaṃ abhāsi:

sn11.5:4.1.eng: ‘I think that this is the only way

sn11.5:4.2.eng: to put a stop to a fool,

sn11.5:4.3.eng: when you know that the other is upset,

sn11.5:5.1.pli: Bhāsitāya kho pana, bhikkhave, sakkena devānamindena gāthāya, devā anumodiṃsu, asurā tuṇhī ahesuṃ.
sn11.5:5.1.eng: The gods applauded Sakka’s verse, while the titans kept silent.

sn11.5:5.2.pli: Atha kho, bhikkhave, sakko devānamindo vepacittiṃ asurindaṃ etadavoca:

sn11.5:5.4.pli: Evaṃ vutte, bhikkhave, vepacitti asurindo imaṃ gāthaṃ abhāsi:

sn11.5:6.4.eng: “He puts up with me out of fear,”

sn11.5:6.5.eng: the simpleton will go after you even harder,

sn11.5:6.6.eng: like a cow chasing someone who runs away.’

sn11.5:7.1.pli: Bhāsitāya kho pana, bhikkhave, vepacittinā asurindena gāthāya asurā anumodiṃsu, devā tuṇhī ahesuṃ.
sn11.5:7.1.eng: The titans applauded Vepacitti’s verse, while the gods kept silent.

sn11.5:7.2.pli: Atha kho, bhikkhave, vepacitti asurindo sakkaṃ devānamindaṃ etadavoca:

sn11.5:7.4.pli: Evaṃ vutte, bhikkhave, sakko devānamindo imā gāthāyo abhāsi:

sn11.5:8.1.eng: ‘Let him think this if he wishes, or not—

sn11.5:8.2.eng: “He puts up with me out of fear.”

sn11.5:8.3.eng: For the highest goal, one’s own,

sn11.5:8.4.eng: naught better than patience is found.

sn11.5:9.3.eng: they call that the ultimate patience,

sn11.5:9.4.eng: for a weakling must always be patient.

sn11.5:10.2.eng: is really just weakness, they say.

sn11.5:10.3.eng: But no-one can challenge a person

sn11.5:10.4.eng: who’s strong, guarded by the teaching.

sn11.5:11.1.eng: When you get angry at an angry person

sn11.5:11.2.eng: you just make things worse for yourself.

sn11.5:11.3.eng: When you don’t get angry at an angry person

sn11.5:11.4.eng: you win a battle hard to win.

sn11.5:12.1.eng: When you know that the other is angry,

sn11.5:12.2.eng: you act for the good of both

sn11.5:12.4.eng: if you’re mindful and stay calm.

sn11.5:14.1.pli: Bhāsitāsu kho pana, bhikkhave, sakkena devānamindena gāthāsu, devā anumodiṃsu, asurā tuṇhī ahesuṃ.
sn11.5:14.1.eng: The gods applauded Sakka’s verses, while the titans kept silent.

sn11.5:14.2.pli: Atha kho, bhikkhave, devānañca asurānañca pārisajjā etadavocuṃ:
sn11.5:14.2.eng: Then the panel of judges consisting of both gods and titans said this,

sn11.5:14.4.pli: Tā ca kho sadaṇḍāvacarā sasatthāvacarā, iti bhaṇḍanaṃ iti viggaho iti kalaho.
sn11.5:14.4.eng: evoke punishment and violence. That’s how you get fights, arguments, and quarrels.

sn11.5:14.6.pli: Tā ca kho adaṇḍāvacarā asatthāvacarā, iti abhaṇḍanaṃ iti aviggaho iti akalaho.
sn11.5:14.6.eng: don’t evoke punishment and violence. That’s how you stay free of fights, arguments, and quarrels.

sn11.5:14.7.eng: Sakka, lord of gods, wins victory by fine words!’

sn11.5:14.8.pli: Iti kho, bhikkhave, sakkassa devānamindassa subhāsitena jayo ahosī”ti.
sn11.5:14.8.eng: And that’s how Sakka came to win victory by fine words.”

sn11.6:1.2.eng: “Once upon a time, mendicants, a battle was fought between the gods and the titans.

sn11.6:1.3.pli: Tasmiṃ kho pana, bhikkhave, saṅgāme asurā jiniṃsu, devā parājiniṃsu.
sn11.6:1.3.eng: In that battle the titans won and the gods lost.

sn11.6:1.4.pli: Parājitā ca kho, bhikkhave, devā apāyaṃsveva uttarenamukhā, abhiyaṃsveva ne asurā.
sn11.6:1.4.eng: Defeated, the gods fled north with the titans in pursuit.

sn11.6:1.5.pli: Atha kho, bhikkhave, sakko devānamindo mātali saṅgāhakaṃ gāthāya ajjhabhāsi:
sn11.6:1.5.eng: Then Sakka, lord of gods, addressed his chariot handler Mātali in verse:

sn11.6:2.1.comm: This verse is also in Ja 31. This delightful story shows the complete transformation of Indra from the war god who revels in slaughter (Atharva Veda 8.8). Indra showed a comparable development in Hinduism, too, for he is said to have saved a wise parrot in his nest when the tree was poisoned (Mahābhārata, Anuśāsanaparva 5).

sn11.6:2.2.eng: in the red silk-cotton woods with your chariot pole.

sn11.6:2.3.eng: I’d rather give up our lives to the titans

sn11.6:2.4.eng: than deprive these birds of their nests.’

sn11.6:3.1.pli: ‘Evaṃ, bhaddantavā’ti kho, bhikkhave, mātali saṅgāhako sakkassa devānamindassa paṭissutvā sahassayuttaṃ ājaññarathaṃ paccudāvattesi.
sn11.6:3.1.eng: ‘Yes, lord,’ replied Mātali. And he turned the chariot back around, with its team of a thousand thoroughbreds.

sn11.6:3.3.pli: ‘paccudāvatto kho dāni sakkassa devānamindassa sahassayutto ājaññaratho.

sn11.6:3.4.pli: Dutiyampi kho devā asurehi saṅgāmessantī’ti bhītā asurapurameva pāvisiṃsu.
sn11.6:3.4.eng: The titans will have to fight the gods a second time!’ Terrified, they retreated right away to the citadel of the titans.

sn11.6:3.5.pli: Iti kho, bhikkhave, sakkassa devānamindassa dhammena jayo ahosī”ti.
sn11.6:3.5.eng: And that’s how Sakka came to win victory by principle.”

sn11.7:1.2.pli: “Bhūtapubbaṃ, bhikkhave, sakkassa devānamindassa rahogatassa paṭisallīnassa evaṃ cetaso parivitakko udapādi:
sn11.7:1.2.eng: “Once upon a time, mendicants, as Sakka, lord of gods, was in private retreat this thought came to his mind,

sn11.7:1.3.pli: ‘yopi me assa supaccatthiko tassapāhaṃ na dubbheyyan’ti.
sn11.7:1.3.eng: ‘I should never betray even a sworn enemy.’

sn11.7:1.4.pli: Atha kho, bhikkhave, vepacitti asurindo sakkassa devānamindassa cetasā cetoparivitakkamaññāya yena sakko devānamindo tenupasaṅkami.
sn11.7:1.4.eng: And then Vepacitti, lord of titans, knowing Sakka’s train of thought, approached him.
sn11.7:1.4.comm: It seems that even when on retreat, Sakka was thinking of Vepacitti, and Vepacitti was thinking of Sakka.

sn11.7:1.5.pli: Addasā kho, bhikkhave, sakko devānamindo vepacittiṃ asurindaṃ dūratova āgacchantaṃ.
sn11.7:1.5.eng: Sakka saw Vepacitti coming off in the distance,

sn11.7:2.1.pli: ‘Yadeva te, mārisa, pubbe cittaṃ, tadeva tvaṃ mā pajahāsī’ti.
sn11.7:2.1.eng: ‘Good fellow, don’t give up the idea you just had!’

sn11.7:3.1.eng: ‘Swear, Vepacitti, that you won’t betray me.’

sn11.7:4.1.eng: ‘Whatever bad things happen to a liar,
sn11.7:4.1.comm: Despite their differences, both sides in a dispute respect morality and each other.

sn11.7:4.2.eng: or to someone who slanders the noble ones,

sn11.7:4.3.eng: or to someone who betrays a friend,

sn11.7:4.6.eng: anyone who betrays you, Sujā’s husband.’”
sn11.7:4.6.comm: Vepacitti is reminding Sakka of their family connection. His wife is the Asura maiden Sujā (SN 11.12:6.1), hence the titans are his brothers (DN 20:12.3).
